articles.headline: Navigating the Takata Airbag Recall
articles.snippet: More than 19 million vehicles have already been recalled, and millions more could be affected in the next few years.
articles.abstract: More than 19 million vehicles have already been recalled, and millions more could be affected in the next few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: People take dozens of uncalculated risks each day. Every time they swallow a pill, bite into a burger or get behind the wheel, they are trusting the systems that delivered those products to market.

articles.headline: Working to Lower Drug Costs by Challenging Questionable Patents
articles.snippet: The Coalition for Affordable Drugs goes after pharmaceutical companies that it says exploit the patent system to keep prices and profits high.
articles.abstract: The Coalition for Affordable Drugs goes after pharmaceutical companies that it says exploit the patent system to keep prices and profits high.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Kyle Bass made a fortune in the financial crisis when his hedge fund, Hayman Capital Management, bet big against subprime mortgages. Now Mr. Bass is wagering against pharmaceutical companies that he says exploit the patent system, keeping drug prices — and their profits — in the stratosphere.

articles.headline: Once in Guantánamo, Afghan Now Leads War Against Taliban and ISIS
articles.snippet: Officials describe Hajji Ghalib as a fiercely effective fighter against the insurgency, and the American military supports his men with airstrikes.
articles.abstract: Officials describe Hajji Ghalib as a fiercely effective fighter against the insurgency, and the American military supports his men with airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hajji Ghalib did just what the American military feared he would after his release from the Guantánamo Bay prison camp: He returned to the Afghan battlefield.

articles.headline: 3 Are Dead in Colorado Springs Shootout at Planned Parenthood Center
articles.snippet: A police officer and two civilians were killed and the authorities arrested a suspect, suggesting he had brought explosive devices with him.
articles.abstract: A police officer and two civilians were killed and the authorities arrested a suspect, suggesting he had brought explosive devices with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — A gun battle erupted inside a Planned Parenthood center here on Friday when a man armed with an assault-style rifle opened fire and began shooting at officers as they rushed to the scene. The authorities reported that three people were killed, a police officer and two civilians, and nine were wounded before the suspect finally surrendered more than five hours after the first shots were fired.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Adele Goes Viral, No Selfies or Tweets Needed
articles.snippet: A 27-year-old mother who pretty much ignores social media is selling more albums than anyone in the sagging music business thought was still possible.
articles.abstract: A 27-year-old mother who pretty much ignores social media is selling more albums than anyone in the sagging music business thought was still possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no one in music quite like Adele.

articles.headline: Foul-Mouthed and Proud of It on the ’16 Campaign Trail
articles.snippet: Seemingly taking a cue from Donald J. Trump, the Republican field is cursing in public at a rate unheard of in modern presidential politics.
articles.abstract: Seemingly taking a cue from Donald J. Trump, the Republican field is cursing in public at a rate unheard of in modern presidential politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump pledged to bomb the, uh, stuffing out of the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Kentucky, Beacon for Health Law, Now a Lab for Its Retreat
articles.snippet: The only Southern state to embrace the Affordable Care Act appears headed in a different direction under a new governor, Matt Bevin.
articles.abstract: The only Southern state to embrace the Affordable Care Act appears headed in a different direction under a new governor, Matt Bevin.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Carolyn Bouchard, a diabetic with a slowly healing shoulder fracture, hurried to see her doctor after Matt Bevin was elected governor here this month.

articles.headline: BTG Pactual, Brazilian Bank, Seeks to Calm Investors After C.E.O.’s Arrest
articles.snippet: BTG Pactual, a Brazilian investment bank, has promised to cooperate with any investigation into corruption involving Petrobras.
articles.abstract: BTG Pactual, a Brazilian investment bank, has promised to cooperate with any investigation into corruption involving Petrobras.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — With its chief executive in jail, BTG Pactual tried to calm investors on Friday, saying that it would cooperate with any investigation.
articles.byline: By Vinod Sreeharsha and Dan Horch

articles.headline: Black Friday Shopping Shifts Online as Stores See Less Foot Traffic
articles.snippet: Total online sales are expected to generate $2.6 billion on Black Friday, a 14 percent increase compared to the same day last year.
articles.abstract: Total online sales are expected to generate $2.6 billion on Black Friday, a 14 percent increase compared to the same day last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In shops across the country, including the empty malls of Georgia and the “not too crazy” crowds at struggling J. Crew, the relative calm that accompanied Black Friday shopping this year belied a frenzy for deals — many of them on the web.

articles.headline: In Colorado, Bustling With Shoppers, Then Gripped by Chaos
articles.snippet: A barrage of bullets turned a busy, snow-covered shopping center in Colorado Springs into a tableau of chaos and fear that lasted over five hours.
articles.abstract: A barrage of bullets turned a busy, snow-covered shopping center in Colorado Springs into a tableau of chaos and fear that lasted over five hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The injured man staggered into the grocery store, his face and chest bloodied. Customers stopped and stared. “He lifted his shirt up, and he had holes in his chest,” said Miranda Schilter, 17, who had been waiting for a drink at an in-store coffee shop.

articles.headline: Chinese Cash Floods U.S. Real Estate Market
articles.snippet: Some of the Chinese money pouring into the global economy has gone into residential property, in major American cities and places like Corinth, Tex.
articles.abstract: Some of the Chinese money pouring into the global economy has gone into residential property, in major American cities and places like Corinth, Tex.
articles.lead_paragraph: Canyon Lake Ranch was once a playground for Christian day campers, and then was a corporate retreat with water-skiing, barbecues and cowboy shoot-’em-up shows. Hawks now circle above 108 sunbaked acres occupied by copperhead snakes, a few coyotes and the occasional construction truck.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Robert Dear, Suspect in Colorado Killings, ‘Preferred to Be Left Alone’
articles.snippet: Mr. Dear lived in a white trailer on a patch of land by the Rocky Mountains and was described as “a mountain culture person.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Dear lived in a white trailer on a patch of land by the Rocky Mountains and was described as “a mountain culture person.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HARTSEL, Colo. — Robert L. Dear Jr. was a man who lived off the grid.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Richard Fausset, Alan Blinder and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: ISIS’ Grip on Libyan City Gives It a Fallback Option
articles.snippet: The Mediterranean port city of Surt has become an actively managed colony of the Islamic State, which has come under growing military and economic pressure in Syria and Iraq.
articles.abstract: The Mediterranean port city of Surt has become an actively managed colony of the Islamic State, which has come under growing military and economic pressure in Syria and Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — Iraqi commanders have been arriving from Syria, and the first public beheadings have started. The local radio stations no longer play music but instead extol the greatness of the Islamic State’s self-proclaimed caliph, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Ben Hubbard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Wealthy Governor and His Friends Are Remaking Illinois
articles.snippet: Unprecedented political spending helped elect a fresh-faced financier. But his ideological vision has unsettled many in the state.
articles.abstract: Unprecedented political spending helped elect a fresh-faced financier. But his ideological vision has unsettled many in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: The richest man in Illinois does not often give speeches. But on a warm spring day two years ago, Kenneth C. Griffin, the billionaire founder of one of the world’s largest hedge funds, rose before a black-tie dinner of the Economic Club of Chicago to deliver an urgent plea to the city’s elite.

articles.headline: Murdoch’s British Tabloids Clean Up Their Acts
articles.snippet: Years after a phone-hacking scandal exposed a pattern of illicit information-gathering, the unspoken laws of tabloids have been reconfigured.
articles.abstract: Years after a phone-hacking scandal exposed a pattern of illicit information-gathering, the unspoken laws of tabloids have been reconfigured.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A July article on a front page of The Sun on Sunday tabloid, owned by Rupert Murdoch, was a classic of its kind. Titled “Lord Coke: Top peer’s drug binges with £200 prostitutes,” its highlights included cross-dressing, bare breasts lined with cocaine and the 69-year-old deputy speaker of the House of Lords excitedly burbling, “I just want to be led astray.”

articles.headline: Behind Puerto Rico’s Woes, a Broadly Powerful Development Bank
articles.snippet: Much of the $72 billion in debt the island cannot repay stems from loans extended and guaranteed by its Government Development Bank
articles.abstract: Much of the $72 billion in debt the island cannot repay stems from loans extended and guaranteed by its Government Development Bank
articles.lead_paragraph: If anything stands as a symbol of how Puerto Rico ended up mired in billions of dollars of debt, it is an oceanside golf resort going to seed some 15 miles east of San Juan.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Paris Deal Would Herald an Important First Step on Climate Change
articles.snippet: There are reasons to believe the Paris negotiations are different from previous failed efforts, but an agreement would hardly halt global warming.
articles.abstract: There are reasons to believe the Paris negotiations are different from previous failed efforts, but an agreement would hardly halt global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Obama and more than 100 world leaders will convene with thousands of diplomats on Monday on the outskirts of Paris to open two weeks of intense negotiations aimed at forging an accord that could begin to avert the most devastating effects of global warming and redefine the economy of the 21st century.

articles.headline: Tensions With Russia Add to a Chill in Turkey’s Economy
articles.snippet: Even before Russia imposed sanctions over the downing of a combat jet, an influx of migrants and a loss of export markets hindered Turkey’s economy.
articles.abstract: Even before Russia imposed sanctions over the downing of a combat jet, an influx of migrants and a loss of export markets hindered Turkey’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESKISEHIR, Turkey — A new high-speed rail line, completed last year, now links Eskisehir with Istanbul to the west and Ankara to the east. A narrow, serpentine river meanders through downtown, spanned by graceful blue bridges at almost every block, drawing tourists. Factories here make everything from cakes and cookies to refrigerators, large Ford freight trucks and aircraft parts.

articles.headline: Tax Status of Museums Questioned by Senators
articles.snippet: Senator Orrin G. Hatch suggested that some museums may offer minimal benefit to the public while enabling donors to reap substantial tax advantages.
articles.abstract: Senator Orrin G. Hatch suggested that some museums may offer minimal benefit to the public while enabling donors to reap substantial tax advantages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee is scrutinizing nearly a dozen private museums opened by individual collectors, questioning whether the tax-exempt status they enjoy provides sufficient public benefit to justify what amounts to a government subsidy.

articles.headline: Predatory Islamic State Wrings Money From Those It Rules
articles.snippet: The earnings from the militants’ violent collection practices total tens of millions of dollars a month, approaching $1 billion a year, according to some estimates.
articles.abstract: The earnings from the militants’ violent collection practices total tens of millions of dollars a month, approaching $1 billion a year, according to some estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three times a month, Mohammad al-Kirayfawai hands $300 to fighters from the Islamic State for the privilege of driving his refrigerated truck full of ice cream and other perishables from Jordan to a part of Iraq where the militants are firmly in charge.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Nicholas Kulish and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Black Friday Just a Day This Year, No Longer a Bellwether
articles.snippet: Black Friday’s importance has waned as retailers have offered holiday sales earlier and longer.
articles.abstract: Black Friday’s importance has waned as retailers have offered holiday sales earlier and longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the lines at Target or Macy’s this Black Friday seemed shorter than in years past, shoppers have the Internet to thank.

articles.headline: Hope for Nefertiti’s Tomb, and Egypt’s Economy
articles.snippet: The prospect of discovering the long-sought tomb of Queen Nefertiti would be momentous. It would also help Egypt’s tourism industry, which has plummeted in recent years because of political unrest.
articles.abstract: The prospect of discovering the long-sought tomb of Queen Nefertiti would be momentous. It would also help Egypt’s tourism industry, which has plummeted in recent years because of political unrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUXOR, Egypt — For weeks, a group of explorers have scanned the walls of a tomb in the Valley of the Kings, using radar and infrared devices, in the hopes that science might confirm one Egyptologist’s theory: that hidden behind a wall of King Tutankhamen’s burial chamber sits the long-sought tomb of Queen Nefertiti.

articles.headline: Discord Between Turkey and Russia Is Fueled by Leaders’ Similarities
articles.snippet: Not long ago, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, earned about the warmest accolade possible from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. That was then.
articles.abstract: Not long ago, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president of Turkey, earned about the warmest accolade possible from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. That was then.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has a new Enemy No. 1.

articles.headline: Shooting at Planned Parenthood Adds to Challenges for Congress
articles.snippet: Congressional supporters and opponents of Planned Parenthood were uncharacteristically subdued over the weekend as they awaited more information about the shooting.
articles.abstract: Congressional supporters and opponents of Planned Parenthood were uncharacteristically subdued over the weekend as they awaited more information about the shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the authorities say they remain uncertain what precisely led a gunman to attack a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado Springs on Friday, a comment attributed to the suspect by a senior law enforcement official — “no more baby parts” — fed directly into an already high-pitched controversy over Planned Parenthood and its practices.
